class_notes:
Classics 201. The Greeks
Louise Pratt
An overview of the cultural achievements of the ancient Greeks in their historical context from the Myceneans (ca. 1300 B.C.E.) to the Roman period (ca. 270 C.E.), with a focus on literature and the history of ideas. The readings will be drawn mainly from primary source material, including representative selections from major authors such as Homer, Sappho, Sophocles, Herodotus, Thucydides, Plato, Plutarch, and Lucian, as well as brief selections from writers on the natural world (Thales, Aristotle), medicine (Hippocrates, Galen), and mathematics (Pythagoras, Euclid).  
 
The course neither requires nor assumes prior experience in the study of the ancient world. All texts will be read and analyzed from English translations.
Course requirements include a midterm, a final, two short writing assignments or a more substantial creative project submitted in two parts, and regular contributions to our Canvas discussions.
course_description: A general survey of ancient Greek literature and culture. Study of the major texts of ancient Greece in their social, historical and archaeological context.
